head.title: Fire Debris Is Sent To U.S. Lab for Tests

identified-content.classifier: Top/News/U.S./U.S. States, Territories and Possessions/New Jersey

hedline.hl1: Fire Debris Is Sent To U.S. Lab for Tests

abstract.p: Sodden debris from unfinished apartment complex destroyed by fast-moving fire in Edgewater, NJ, has been sent to federal laboratory for analysis (S)

block.p: Sodden debris from the unfinished apartment complex destroyed by a fast-moving fire Wednesday night in Edgewater has been sent to a federal laboratory for analysis, the authorities said today.

Edgar A. Domenech, the head of the New York office of the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, said arson investigators collected the material at the site late Friday and sent it over the weekend to the bureau's national laboratory in Rockville, Md.
Sodden debris from the unfinished apartment complex destroyed by a fast-moving fire Wednesday night in Edgewater has been sent to a federal laboratory for analysis, the authorities said today.

Edgar A. Domenech, the head of the New York office of the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, said arson investigators collected the material at the site late Friday and sent it over the weekend to the bureau's national laboratory in Rockville, Md.

Mr. Domenech said the results, expected by the end of the week, would be given to the Bergen County prosecutor, William H. Schmidt, whose office here would file any criminal charges stemming from the fire.

The federal agency usually helps investigate fires that cause more than $1 million in damage and significantly disrupt communities. Among other things, the bureau's Maryland lab specializes in detecting traces of flammable liquids in fire rubble.
